FedFDP: Federated Learning with Fairness and Differential Privacy

Xinpeng Ling1∗    Jie Fu1 These authors contributed equally.    Zhili Chen1 Corresponding author.    Kuncan Wang1    Huifa Li1    Tong Cheng1    Guanying Xu2    Qin Li3 1East China Normal University, 2Central South University,
3Hunan University Of Technology and Business.
{xpling, jie.fu}@stu.ecnu.edu.cn, zhlchen@sei.ecnu.edu.cn,
{kuncan.wang, huifali, tcheng}@stu.ecnu.edu.cn, guanying.xu@csu.edu.cn, qinli@hutb.edu.cn
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a new machine learning paradigm to overcome the challenge of data silos and has garnered significant attention. However, through our observations, a globally effective trained model may performance disparities in different clients. This implies that the jointly trained models by clients may lead to unfair outcomes. On the other hand, relevant studies indicate that the transmission of gradients or models in federated learning can also give rise to privacy leakage issues, such as membership inference attacks.

To address the first issue mentioned above, we propose a federated algorithm with fairness, termed FedFair. Building upon FedFair, we introduce privacy protection to form the FedFDP algorithm to address the second issue mentioned above. In FedFDP, we devise a fairness-aware clipping strategy to achieve differential privacy while adjusting fairness. Additionally, for the extra uploaded loss values, we present an adaptive clipping approach to maximize utility. Furthermore, we theoretically prove that our algorithm converges and ensures differential privacy. Lastly, Extensive experimental results demonstrate that FedFair and FedFDP significantly outperforms state-of-the-art solutions in terms of model performance and fairness. The code is accessible at https://anonymous.4open.science/r/FedFDP-E754.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) McMahan et al. (2017) is a distributed machine learning framework that allows clients to collaboratively train a shared model without revealing their individual datasets. After training their local models, each client transmits only the model parameters, not the raw training data, to a central server. The server aggregates these parameters to update the global model, which is then sent back to clients for further training. Because its ability to overcome data silos by jointly improving model performance without the need to upload local data, FL has gained significant attention in recent year Zhu et al. (2021)Lee et al. (2022). In particular, many studies have made great breakthroughs in model performance Wang et al. (2020); Li et al. (2020a, 2021b) and communication costs Wang et al. (2019); Ling et al. (2023) in FL.

However, recent research indicates that trained parameters can leak data privacy, such as the recovery of original data Zhu et al. (2019) or the membership inference attack Song et al. (2017). Moreover, Melis et al. Melis et al. (2022) demonstrated that clients’ training data can be leaked through shared models. In order to enhance data privacy in the FL, numerous scholars have begun integrating techniques such as differential privacy (DP) Dwork et al. (2014), homomorphic encryption Paillier (1999), and secure multi-party computation Yao (1982) into the federated learning framework. Among these, DP has emerged as the most widely acknowledged approach for privacy protection in federated learning, owing to its minimal computational overhead and rigorous mathematical framework. Many works Abadi et al. (2016); Carlini et al. (2019); Feldman (2020) have demonstrated that by adding proper DP noise in the training phase, the resulted machine learning models can prevent unintentional leakage of private training data, such as membership inference attacks.

Another easily overlooked critical issue in federated learning is fairness. The globally trained model collaboratively by clients may exhibit significant performance disparities across datasets held by different clients. As shown in Fig.1, where the red dots indicate the test accuracy of the global model across various clients after the completion of federated learning using the FedAvg McMahan et al. (2017) algorithm. And we can see the globally trained model applied to individual clients, the performance significant performance disparities across differential clients. More and more scholars have begun to notice this unfair phenomenon and initiated research on it  Wang et al. (2020); Li et al. (2020b).

While numerous articles separately discuss fairness and differential privacy protection in federated learning, there is a lack of research integrating both aspects into federated learning. Balancing model performance, fairness, and differential privacy protection in federated learning presents a challenging problem. This paper aims to investigate fairness and differential privacy protection mechanisms in federated learning. By analyzing the relationship between them, we propose a federated learning framework that ensures both fairness and differential privacy protection, effectively guaranteeing model performance.

Our main contributions are listed below:

  1. 1.

    Firstly, we propose a fairness-aware federated algorithm, denoted as algorithm FedFair by designing a new local loss function that is constructed to simultaneously optimize the two objectives of fairness and model performance (Section 4). FedFair algorithm achieves the excellent fairness, as shown by the green dots in Fig.1.

  2. 2.

    Building upon FedFair, we propose algorithm FedFDP to achieve differential privacy protection (Section 5) . Particularly, we device a fairness-aware gradient clipping strategy to ensures both differential privacy and allows for the adjustment of fairness in federated learning (Section 5.1). Additionally, we propose an adaptive clipping approach method for the additional loss values uploaded by each client to achieve optimal utility (Section 5.2).

  3. 3.

    Furthermore, we demonstrate there exist an optimal fairness parameter λ𝜆\lambda value to balance the model performance and fairness through the convergence analysis (Section 6).

  4. 4.

    And then, we perform privacy loss analysis of our algorithm FedFDP by the notion of Rényi differential privacy (RDP) to prove that it satisfies the differential privacy (Section 7).

  5. 5.

    Lastly, through a comprehensive empirical evaluation on three public datasets, we confirm that FedFair and FedFDP outperforms the state-of-the-art solutions in terms of model performance and fairness (Section 8).

2 Related Work

2.1 Fairness in Federated Learning

In the field of machine learning, a multitude of fairness concepts have been advanced (Mehrabi et al. Mehrabi et al. (2021), Yuxin et al. Shi et al. (2021)), each highlighting specific facets and addressing the concerns of diverse stakeholder groups. For instance, Mohri et al. Mohri et al. (2019) advocate for Good-Intent Fairness, while Zhou et al. Zhou et al. (2021) embrace Selection Fairness. Cong and Lyu et al. Cong et al. (2020)Lyu et al. (2020) employ principles from game theory Rabin (1993) to steer the allocation of rewards.

Currently, the predominant fairness criterion in Federated Learning is “Performance Parity”, as proposed by Li et al. Li et al. (2020b). This criterion aims to ensure fairness by evaluating the consistency of performance across different client devices in federated learning. This definition is widely adopted. Zhao et al. Zhao and Joshi (2022) suggested replacing the loss amplification mechanism in Li et al. (2020b) with a straightforward weight reallocation mechanism. Li et al. Li et al. (2021b) focus on optimizing the fairness of local models in personalized federated learning.

2.2 Federated Learning with Differential Privacy

Federated learning with differential privacy has become a common privacy protection method in federated learning. Enayat et al. Ullah et al. (2023) dynamically adjust the compression rate to minimize communication rounds in federated learning by responding to changes in training loss. Zhou et al. Zhou et al. (2023) investigated the effects of local iterations when utilizing the Laplace mechanism for perturbation. Fu et al. Fu et al. (2022) introduced adaptive noise adding, customizing it for different clients and communication rounds based on observed fluctuations in loss values. Ling et al. Ling et al. (2023) determined the optimal number of local epochs through convergence analysis, striking a balance between communication resources and privacy budget. Raouf et al. Kerkouche et al. (2021) improved model accuracy by updating only a fixed subset of model weights while keeping others unchanged.

The aforementioned works each independently address either fairness or privacy protection in federated learning. To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to concurrently consider both fairness and privacy in the context of federated learning.

3 Preliminaries

3.1 Federated Learning

We use 𝐰tisubscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}^{i}_{t} signifies the model acquired from client i𝑖i at iteration t𝑡t, while 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t} denotes the server-aggregated model. The objective of Federated Learning is to minimize F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰F(\mathbf{w}), in other words, to seek:

𝐰∗≜arg⁡min⁡F​(𝐰).≜superscript𝐰𝐹𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*}\triangleq\arg\min F(\mathbf{w}). (1)

The function F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot) is defined as follows:

F​(𝐰)≜∑i=1Npi​Fi​(𝐰).≜𝐹𝐰superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰F(\mathbf{w})\triangleq\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}F_{i}(\mathbf{w}). (2)

Here, Fi​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑖⋅F_{i}(\cdot) represents the local loss function of client i𝑖i. The weights are defined as pi=|Di||D|subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖𝐷p_{i}=\frac{|D_{i}|}{|D|}, ∑i=1Npi=1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖1\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}=1, Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} represents the dataset of client i𝑖i, and D𝐷D represents the union of all Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}.

3.2 DPSGD

In gradient-based methods, DPSGDAbadi et al. (2016) is widely used in privacy preservation. It performs per-sample gradient clipping and noise addition:

  • •

    Firstly, computing the gradient of loss function:

    gti,j=∇Fi​(𝐰ti,ξj).subscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑖𝑗𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑖subscript𝜉𝑗g^{i,j}_{t}=\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i},\xi_{j}). (3)
  • •

    Secondly, clipping the gradient of per-sample to get the sensitivity:

    g^ti,j=gti,j/max⁡(1,‖gti,j‖C).subscriptsuperscript^𝑔𝑖𝑗𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑖𝑗𝑡1normsubscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑖𝑗𝑡𝐶\hat{g}^{i,j}_{t}=g^{i,j}_{t}/\max\left(1,\frac{\|g^{i,j}_{t}\|}{C}\right). (4)
  • •

    Thirdly, adding Gaussian noise with mean 0 and standard deviation C​σ𝐶𝜎C\sigma to the sum of clipped gradients:

    g~ti=1|ℬi|​(∑j=1|ℬi|g^ti,j+C​σ⋅𝒩​(0,𝐈)).subscriptsuperscript~𝑔𝑖𝑡1subscriptℬ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscriptℬ𝑖subscriptsuperscript^𝑔𝑖𝑗𝑡⋅𝐶𝜎𝒩0𝐈\tilde{g}^{i}_{t}=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{B}_{i}|}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{|\mathcal{B}_{i}|}\hat{g}^{i,j}_{t}+C\sigma\cdot\mathcal{N}(0,\mathbf{I})\right). (5)

The final step is to proceed with gradient descent as usual. Here, C𝐶C represents the clipping bound, and σ𝜎\sigma is the noise multiplier. If each client in FL uses DPSGD as the gradient descent method to protect their private data, FL will transform into Differentially Private Federated Learning (DPFL).

3.3 Fairness in Federated Learning

Definition 1.

(Fairness of performance distributionLi et al. (2020b)) For trained models 𝐰1subscript𝐰1\mathbf{w}_{1} and 𝐰2subscript𝐰2\mathbf{w}_{2}, we informally say that model 𝐰1subscript𝐰1\mathbf{w}_{1} provides a more fair solution to the federated learning objective in Equation (1) than model 𝐰2subscript𝐰2\mathbf{w}_{2} if the performance of model 𝐰1subscript𝐰1\mathbf{w}_{1} on the N𝑁N devices is more uniform than the performance of model 𝐰2subscript𝐰2\mathbf{w}_{2} on the N𝑁N devices.

In this study, we employ the loss of model denote the performance. Equation (6) represents the specific form of fairness in federated learning in this paper, which is the weighted variance of the loss values of global trained model 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} across all clients. Essentially, the smaller the value of ΨΨ\Psi, the fairer the 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} for all clients.

Ψ​(𝐰)≜∑i=1Npi​(Fi​(𝐰)−F​(𝐰))2.≜Ψ𝐰superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝐰𝐹𝐰2\Psi(\mathbf{w})\triangleq\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}\left(F_{i}(\mathbf{w})-F(\mathbf{w})\right)^{2}. (6)

4 Proposed Algorithm: FedFair

In the previous section, we identified the performance objective function as shown in Equation (2) and the fairness objective function as shown in Equation (6). Both of these objective functions are composed of individual client objectives. In this section, we will focus on the performance and fairness of each client and combine these two objectives to construct a new objective function, based on which we propose a fair federated learning algorithm.

We simultaneously optimize performance and fairness, and can get the optimization objective for client i𝑖i as:

min𝐰ti⁡Hi​(𝐰ti)=Fi​(𝐰ti)+λ2​(Fi​(𝐰ti)−F​(𝐰t))2,subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑖𝑡subscript𝐻𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑖𝑡subscript𝐹𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑖𝑡𝜆2superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑖𝑡𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡2\min_{\mathbf{w}^{i}_{t}}H_{i}(\mathbf{w}^{i}_{t})=F_{i}(\mathbf{w}^{i}_{t})+\frac{\lambda}{2}\left(F_{i}(\mathbf{w}^{i}_{t})-F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right)^{2}, (7)

where F​(𝐰t)=∑i=1Npi​Fi​(𝐰t−1)𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡1F(\mathbf{w}_{t})=\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t-1})111The reason for F​(𝐰t)≠F​(𝐰t,ξt​e​s​t)𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝜉𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\neq F(\mathbf{w}_{t},\xi_{test}) is that the test data ξt​e​s​tsubscript𝜉𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡\xi_{test} from the server cannot be used for training.and λ𝜆\lambda is a hyperparameter used to adjust the degree of fairness, λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0. When λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0, the algorithm becomes traditional federated learning. When λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\rightarrow\infty, the algorithm only focus on fairness.

The gradient of Equation (7) as follows:

The stochastic gradient descent for Equation (7) as show:

Therefore, our approach can be viewed as establishing an adaptive learning rate that allows the model update to achieve both performance and fairness objectives simultaneously. Based on these principles, we introduce the FedFair algorithm, as depicted in Algorithm 1.

  • •

    Server (lines 1-1): The server executes T𝑇T rounds of communication, each round sending the aggregated model 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t} and the loss F​(𝐰t)𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡F(\mathbf{w}_{t}) to clients.

  • •

    Local (lines 1-1): For E𝐸E epochs and each batch b𝑏b, we compute the adaptive learning rate ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i} in lines 1-1. For line 1, we execute gradient descent by using ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i}.

Furthermore, as the iterations advance, the model progressively prioritizes fairness, leading to a reduction in ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i}. In comparison to training methods with a fixed learning rate, learning rate decay can accelerate the convergence of gradient-based methods Zinkevich (2003).

5 Proposed Algorithm: FedFDP

In this section, we propose the FedFDP by integrating differential privacy protection base on FedFair. The flow of FedFDP algorithm as shown in Fig. 2. The FedFDP algorithm adds the following two additional processes to FedFair. Firstly, in Section 5.1, we present a fair-clipping strategy that not only achieves sensitivity but also allows for adjustments to the level of fairness. Furthermore, in Section 5.2, we expand the use of differential privacy protection to the additional loss values that local clients need to upload, suggesting an adaptive clipping method to maximize utility. The overall FedFDP algorithm is described in Section 5.3.

5.1 Fair-clipping Strategy for Gradient

In the general DPSGD algorithm Fu et al. (2023); Abadi et al. (2016); Bu et al. (2022); Yang et al. (2022), per-sample clipping is an essential process for obtaining sensitivity. In order to be compatible with per-sample clipping, we expand our objective function of client i𝑖i in FedFair, Equation (7), into Equation (10):

min𝐰ti⁡Hi​(𝐰ti,ξj)≜Fi​(𝐰ti,ξj)+λ2​(Fi​(𝐰ti,ξj)−F​(𝐰t))2,≜subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑖subscript𝐻𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑖subscript𝜉𝑗subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑖subscript𝜉𝑗𝜆2superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑖subscript𝜉𝑗𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡2\min_{\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i}}H_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i},\xi_{j})\triangleq F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i},\xi_{j})+\frac{\lambda}{2}\left(F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i},\xi_{j})-F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right)^{2}, (10)

where ξj∈ℬtisubscript𝜉𝑗superscriptsubscriptℬ𝑡𝑖\xi_{j}\in\mathcal{B}_{t}^{i}, j={1,2,⋯,|ℬi|}𝑗12⋯subscriptℬ𝑖j=\{1,2,\cdots,|\mathcal{B}_{i}|\}, and |ℬi|subscriptℬ𝑖|\mathcal{B}_{i}| is the batch size of client i𝑖i.

Next, we compute the gradient of Equation (10):

∇Hi​(𝐰ti,ξj)∇subscript𝐻𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑖subscript𝜉𝑗\displaystyle\nabla H_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i},\xi_{j}) =∇Fi​(𝐰ti,ξj)+λ⋅Δl​o​s​sj⋅∇Fi​(𝐰ti,ξj)absent∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑖subscript𝜉𝑗⋅𝜆superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑙𝑜𝑠𝑠𝑗∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑖subscript𝜉𝑗\displaystyle=\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i},\xi_{j})+\lambda\cdot\Delta_{loss}^{j}\cdot\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i},\xi_{j})
=(1+λ⋅Δl​o​s​sj)⋅∇Fi​(𝐰ti,ξj),absent⋅1⋅𝜆superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑙𝑜𝑠𝑠𝑗∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑖subscript𝜉𝑗\displaystyle=\left(1+\lambda\cdot\Delta_{loss}^{j}\right)\cdot\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i},\xi_{j}), (11)

where Δl​o​s​sj=Fi​(𝐰ti,ξj)−F​(𝐰t)superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑙𝑜𝑠𝑠𝑗subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑖subscript𝜉𝑗𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡\Delta_{loss}^{j}=F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i},\xi_{j})-F(\mathbf{w}_{t}).

To achieve differential privacy protection, we replace loss function gradient by Equation (5.1) based on Equations (3)-(5), and reorganize the gradient descent equation for client i𝑖i:

𝐰t+1isuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑖\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{i} =𝐰ti−η|ℬi|[∑j=1|ℬi|(1+λ⋅Δl​o​s​sj)​∇Fi​(𝐰ti,ξj)max⁡(1,(1+λ⋅Δl​o​s​sj)​‖∇Fi​(𝐰ti,ξj)‖C)\displaystyle=\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i}-\frac{\eta}{|\mathcal{B}_{i}|}[\sum^{|\mathcal{B}_{i}|}_{j=1}\frac{\left(1+\lambda\cdot\Delta^{j}_{loss}\right)\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i},\xi_{j})}{\max\left(1,\frac{\left(1+\lambda\cdot\Delta^{j}_{loss}\right)\|\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i},\xi_{j})\|}{C}\right)}
+σC⋅𝒩(0,𝐈)]\displaystyle\quad+\sigma C\cdot\mathcal{N}(0,\mathbf{I})]
=𝐰ti−η|ℬi|​[∑j=1|ℬi|Cti,j⋅∇Fi​(𝐰ti,ξj)+σ​C⋅𝒩​(0,𝐈)],absentsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑖𝜂subscriptℬ𝑖delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptℬ𝑖𝑗1⋅subscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑖𝑗𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑖subscript𝜉𝑗⋅𝜎𝐶𝒩0𝐈\displaystyle=\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i}-\frac{\eta}{|\mathcal{B}_{i}|}[\sum^{|\mathcal{B}_{i}|}_{j=1}C^{i,j}_{t}\cdot\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i},\xi_{j})+\sigma C\cdot\mathcal{N}(0,\mathbf{I})], (12)

where:

Cti,j=min⁡(1+λ⋅Δl​o​s​sj,C‖∇Fi​(𝐰ti,ξj)‖).subscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑖𝑗𝑡1⋅𝜆subscriptsuperscriptΔ𝑗𝑙𝑜𝑠𝑠𝐶norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑖subscript𝜉𝑗C^{i,j}_{t}=\min\left(1+\lambda\cdot\Delta^{j}_{loss},\frac{C}{\|\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i},\xi_{j})\|}\right). (13)

Hence, our strategy can be regarded as an fair-clipping technique, tailored to meet the demands of differential privacy while also nurturing fairness within the model. When λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0, Equation (13) corresponds to the traditional DP clipping method, and FedFDP no longer ensures fairness. For large C𝐶C, Equation (13) simplifies to the first term, prompting FedFDP to adjust towards enhanced fairness. Conversely, for small C𝐶C, Equation (13) simplifies to the second term, resulting in the gradient being clipped to the bound C𝐶C. Our conclusions can be verified from the experiments 5.

5.2 Adaptive Clipping Method for Loss

Since the calculation of Δl​o​s​sjsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑙𝑜𝑠𝑠𝑗\Delta_{loss}^{j} requires clients to upload Fi​(𝐰t)subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}), we need to incorporate differential privacy to ensure that the algorithm does not compromise privacy. As shown in lines 2-2 of Algorithm 2, We need to clip Fi​(𝐰t)subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}) to the interval [0,Cli,t]0superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑙𝑖𝑡[0,C_{l}^{i,t}], and then add Gaussian noise with a mean of 00 and a standard deviation of Cli,t⋅σl⋅superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑙𝑖𝑡subscript𝜎𝑙C_{l}^{i,t}\cdot\sigma_{l} to ensure differential privacy. However, setting an appropriate clipping bound Cli,tsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑙𝑖𝑡C_{l}^{i,t} for Fi​(𝐰t)subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}) is challenging. A large Cli,tsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑙𝑖𝑡C_{l}^{i,t} helps avoid loss of fidelity to the original values, but it also leads to large injected noise.

Based on the data heterogeneity of federated learning, we propose an adaptive clipping method for Fi​(𝐰t)subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}). For the i𝑖i-th client, the adaptive clipping method uses the d​i​f​f​e​r​e​n​t​i​a​l​l​y𝑑𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑒𝑟𝑒𝑛𝑡𝑖𝑎𝑙𝑙𝑦differentially p​r​i​v​a​t​e𝑝𝑟𝑖𝑣𝑎𝑡𝑒private m​e​a​n𝑚𝑒𝑎𝑛mean o​f𝑜𝑓of t​h​e𝑡ℎ𝑒the p​r​e​v​i​o​u​s𝑝𝑟𝑒𝑣𝑖𝑜𝑢𝑠previous r​o​u​n​d𝑟𝑜𝑢𝑛𝑑round as the clipping bound for the current round. The clipping bound Cli,tsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑙𝑖𝑡C_{l}^{i,t} for round t𝑡t and client i𝑖i is defined as follows, when Fi​(𝐰t−1)subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡1F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t-1}) is the individual loss of the previous round and σlt−1subscriptsuperscript𝜎𝑡1𝑙\sigma^{t-1}_{l} is the individual noise multiplier of the previous round.

Cli,t=∑j=1|ℬi|clip⁡(Fi​(𝐰t−1,ξj))+𝒩​(0,(Cli,t−1⋅σl)2)|ℬi|,superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑙𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscriptℬ𝑖clipsubscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡1subscript𝜉𝑗𝒩0superscript⋅superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑙𝑖𝑡1subscript𝜎𝑙2subscriptℬ𝑖C_{l}^{i,t}=\frac{\sum_{j=1}^{|\mathcal{B}_{i}|}\operatorname{clip}\left(F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t-1},\xi_{j})\right)+\mathcal{N}\left(0,({C_{l}^{i,t-1}}\cdot{\sigma_{l}})^{2}\right)}{|\mathcal{B}_{i}|}, (14)

where

clip⁡(Fi​(𝐰t−1i,ξj))=min⁡(Cli,t−1,max⁡(0,Fi​(𝐰t−1i,ξj))),clipsubscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑖subscript𝜉𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑙𝑖𝑡10subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑖subscript𝜉𝑗\operatorname{clip}\left(F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t-1}^{i},\xi_{j})\right)=\min({C_{l}^{i,t-1}},\max(0,F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t-1}^{i},\xi_{j}))), (15)

To ensure the achievement of differential privacy during the clipping process, we use the noise-added loss as the clipping bound Cli,tsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑙𝑖𝑡C_{l}^{i,t}. Each round’s clipping bound adheres to the post-processing nature of differential privacy when t={1,…,T}𝑡1…𝑇t=\{1,\dots,T\}.

5.3 Overall Algorithm

We utilize the equation form presented in (12) to enhance Algorithm 2. Compared with the Algorithm 1, FedFDP solely necessitates the application of differential privacy to gradient and loss.

  • •

    DPSGD (lines 2-2): In lines 2-2, we compute the fair-clipping bound Cti,jsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑡𝑖𝑗C_{t}^{i,j} and the per-sample gradient ∇Fi​(𝐰ti,ξj)∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑖subscript𝜉𝑗\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i},\xi_{j}) to get the processed gradient g~ti,jsuperscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑡𝑖𝑗\tilde{g}_{t}^{i,j}. Then, we add mean 0 noise to the sum of per-sample processed gradient g~ti,jsuperscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑡𝑖𝑗\tilde{g}_{t}^{i,j} in line 2 and execute the gradient decent.

  • •

    DP for local loss (lines 2-2): As described in 5.2, add noise to the clipped local loss by using adaptive clipping bound Cli,tsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑙𝑖𝑡C_{l}^{i,t}.

6 Utility Analysis

In this section, we examine the convergence of the FedFDP algorithm to identify an optimal λ𝜆\lambda that minimizes the convergence bound.

6.1 Convergence Analysis

We analyze the convergence of Algorithm 2 and derive insights on selecting the hyperparameter λ𝜆\lambda based on the convergence upper bound. Prior to proving this, we need to establish several assumptions:

Assumption 1.

F1,⋯,FNsubscript𝐹1⋯subscript𝐹𝑁F_{1},\cdots,F_{N} are all L-smooth: for all 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v} and 𝐰,Fi​(𝐯)≤Fi​(𝐰)+(𝐯−𝐰)T​∇Fi​(𝐰)+L2​‖𝐯−𝐰‖2𝐰subscript𝐹𝑖𝐯subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰superscript𝐯𝐰𝑇∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰𝐿2superscriptnorm𝐯𝐰2\mathbf{w},F_{i}(\mathbf{v})\leq F_{i}(\mathbf{w})+(\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{w})^{T}\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w})+\frac{L}{2}\|\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{w}\|^{2}.

Assumption 2.

F1,⋯,FNsubscript𝐹1⋯subscript𝐹𝑁F_{1},\cdots,F_{N} are all μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex: for all 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v} and 𝐰,Fi​(𝐯)≥Fi​(𝐰)+(𝐯−𝐰)T​∇Fi​(𝐰)+μ2​‖𝐯−𝐰‖2𝐰subscript𝐹𝑖𝐯subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰superscript𝐯𝐰𝑇∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰𝜇2superscriptnorm𝐯𝐰2\mathbf{w},F_{i}(\mathbf{v})\geq F_{i}(\mathbf{w})+(\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{w})^{T}\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w})+\frac{\mu}{2}\|\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{w}\|^{2}.

Assumption 3.

Let ξjsubscript𝜉𝑗\xi_{j} be sampled from the i𝑖i-th device’s local data uniformly at random. The expected squared norm of stochastic gradients is uniformly bounded, i.e., ‖∇Fi​(𝐰ti,ξj)‖≤Gnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑖subscript𝜉𝑗𝐺\left\|\nabla F_{i}\left(\mathbf{w}_{t}^{i},\xi_{j}\right)\right\|\leq G for all i=1,⋯,N𝑖1⋯𝑁i=1,\cdots,N , t=1,⋯,T−1𝑡1⋯𝑇1t=1,\cdots,T-1 and j=1,⋯,|ℬi|𝑗1⋯subscriptℬ𝑖j=1,\cdots,|\mathcal{B}_{i}|

Theorem 1.

7 Privacy Analysis

Because each client’s locally trained pair of data samples has the same sampling rate and noise multiplier in each round, each client has the same privacy loss in each round. As a result, we only assess each client’s privacy loss from the perspective of a single client. Following that, we examine the privacy loss of FedPDF for the i𝑖i-th client as follows.

Theorem 2.

(Privacy loss of FedFDP). The privacy loss in i𝑖i-th client of FedFDP satisfies:

(ϵi,δi)=(Rm​o​d​e​li(α)+Rl​o​s​si(α)+ln((α−1)/α)−(lnδ+lnα)/(α−1),δ),\displaystyle\begin{split}\begin{aligned} (\epsilon^{i},\delta^{i})=&(R_{model}^{i}(\alpha)+R_{loss}^{i}(\alpha)+\ln((\alpha-1)/\alpha)\\ &-(\ln\delta+\ln\alpha)/(\alpha-1),\delta),\end{aligned}\end{split} (18)

where 0<δ<10𝛿10<\delta<1, Rm​o​d​e​li​(α)superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑚𝑜𝑑𝑒𝑙𝑖𝛼R_{model}^{i}(\alpha) is the RDP of wt+1isuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑡1𝑖w_{t+1}^{i} is computed by Theorem 3 in Appendix A.2, and Rl​o​s​si(αR_{loss}^{i}(\alpha is the RDP of F~i​(𝐰t+1i)subscript~𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑖\tilde{F}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{i}) which is computed by Theorem 4 in Appendix A.2.

The details of the proof please refer to Appendix A.2.

8 Experiments

In this section, we conduct experiments to demonstrate the performance and fairness of FedFair and FedFDP using three real datasets. Additionally, we investigate the impact of various factors on FedFDP, such as fairness hyperparameter λ𝜆\lambda, original clipping bound C𝐶C, heterogeneity and scalability. The impact of heterogeneity and scalability please refer to Appendix A.3).

8.1 Default Settings

We conducted experiments on three computer vision (CV) datasets: MNIST LeCun et al. (1998), FashionMNIST Xiao et al. (2017), and CIFAR10 Krizhevsky (2009). And we comparised our algorithms to six baselines, which include FedAvgMcMahan et al. (2017), SCAFFLODKarimireddy et al. (2020), FedProxLi et al. (2020a), FedDynAcar et al. (2021), ALI-DPFLLing et al. (2023) and q-FFLLi et al. (2020b). For the details of parameters settings and the descriptions of baselines please refer to Appendix A.3.1.

8.2 Results

Performance and Fairness. The experimental results of the FedFair algorithm and baseline methods are shown in Table 1. FedFair notably enhances fairness while maintaining substantial model performance across the MNIST, FashionMNIST, and CIFAR10 datasets, with respective increases of 17.0%, 25.7%, and 9.5%. And Table 2 shows the experimental results of the FedFDP algorithm and baseline methods. Under the same privacy budget, FedFDP demonstrates improvements in model accuracy of 1.2%, 1.8%, and 0.4% compared to the best baseline on the three datasets, while also enhancing fairness by 30.3%, 6.7%, and 27.8% respectively compared to the best baseline.

Impact of different λ𝜆\lambda. We investigated the correlation between λ𝜆\lambda and fairness ΨΨ\Psi in FedFDF algorithm. As depicted in Figure 4, our findings align with the theoretical analysis in Section 6.1: an initial increase in λ𝜆\lambda leads to a decrease in ΨΨ\Psi, followed by an increase.

Impact of different C𝐶C. In Section 5.1, we emphasized that excessively large or small values of C𝐶C cannot ensure both performance and fairness simultaneously. As illustrated in Figure 5, we examined the correlation between C𝐶C, performance, and fairness across two datasets, with C𝐶C taking values of [0.01, 0.1, 1, 5, 10]. Although ΨΨ\Psi reaches its minimum when C=1𝐶1C=1, at this point, due to excessive noise addition, the model does not converge. As C𝐶C continues to increase, the model’s performance further deteriorates, resulting in an increase in ΨΨ\Psi. When C=0.1𝐶0.1C=0.1, both accuracy and ΨΨ\Psi achieve relatively good values.

9 Conclusion

In this paper, firstly, we propose a FedFair algorithm effectively addresses fairness concerns by optimizing a novel local loss function. Building upon FedFair, we propose the FedFDP, incorporates a fairness-aware gradient clipping strategy and an adaptive clipping method for additional loss values to achieve both fairness and differential privacy protection. And then, through convergence analysis, we determine the existence of an optimal fairness parameter, λ𝜆\lambda, striking a balance between model performance and fairness. We conduct a comprehensive privacy analysis of our approach using RDP and validate our algorithms through extensive experiments. The results indicate that FedFair and FedFDP significantly outperforms state-of-the-art solutions in terms of model performance and fairness. We believe our work contributes a valuable FL framework for addressing fairness and privacy challenges.

A.2 Proof of Theorem 2

As Algorithm 2 shown, the i𝑖i-th client will return model parameters 𝐰t+1isuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑖\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{i} and loss value F~i​(𝐰t+1i)subscript~𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑖\tilde{F}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{i}) before the server aggregates the model parameters in round t+1𝑡1t+1. 𝐰t+1isuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑖\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{i} and F~i​(𝐰t+1i)subscript~𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑖\tilde{F}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{i}) both access the private training data of local client, so they are both to perform differential privacy preservation, as in lines 2-2 and lines 2-2 of the Algorithm 2, respectively. We will analyze their privacy with RDP separately and finally combine their privacy loss to get the overall privacy loss of FedFDP algorithm.

A.2.3 Proof Loss of FedFDP

Since both wTisuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑇𝑖w_{T}^{i} and F~i​(𝐰t+1i)subscript~𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑖\tilde{F}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t+1}^{i}) access the training set, we need to combine their RDP sequentially using Definition 3, and then use Lemma 2 to convert it to (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP. Therefore, the Theorem 2 is hold.

Lemma 2.

(Conversion from RDP to DP Balle et al. [2020]). if a randomized mechanism f:D→ℝ:𝑓→𝐷ℝf:D\rightarrow\mathbb{R} satisfies (α,R)𝛼𝑅(\alpha,R)-RDP ,then it satisfies(R+ln⁡((α−1)/α)−(ln⁡δ+ln⁡α)/(α−1),δ)𝑅𝛼1𝛼𝛿𝛼𝛼1𝛿(R+\ln((\alpha-1)/\alpha)-(\ln\delta+\ln\alpha)/(\alpha-1),\delta)-DP for any 0<δ<10𝛿10<\delta<1.

A.3 Experiment Settings

A.3.1 Parameters Settings

For all datasets, we adopted a widely used heterogeneous settingsLin et al. [2020]Li et al. [2021a] to 10 clients which controlled by a Dirichlet distribution denoted as D​i​r​(β)𝐷𝑖𝑟𝛽Dir(\beta), where a smaller β𝛽\beta indicates a higher degree of heterogeneity. We set the default value of β=0.1𝛽0.1\beta=0.1 Lin et al. [2020]Wang et al. [2020].

In all datasets, we use a 4-layer CNN architecture McMahan et al. [2017] which consists of two convolutional layers and two fully connected layers. For FedFair and its baseline algorithms, we set learning rate η=0.1𝜂0.1\eta=0.1. For FedFDP and its baseline algorithms, we set the η=1.0𝜂1.0\eta=1.0, the batch sample ratio q=0.05𝑞0.05q=0.05, clipping bound for gradient C=0.1𝐶0.1C=0.1, the noise multipliers for gradient σ=2.0𝜎2.0\sigma=2.0, the privacy budget ϵ=3.52italic-ϵ3.52\epsilon=3.52 and the δ=1​e−5𝛿1𝑒5\delta=1e-5. In particular, for the loss values in the FedFDP algorithm that additionally require differential privacy processing, we set the clipping bound for loss Cl=2.5subscript𝐶𝑙2.5C_{l}=2.5 and the noise multipliers for loss σl=5.0subscript𝜎𝑙5.0\sigma_{l}=5.0.

In all experiments, we use 25% of the data will form the test dataset, and the remaining 75% of the data will be used for training. All tasks will be repeated five times using different random seeds, and the mean and standard deviation will be reported.

A.3.2 Baselines introduction

The baseline methods included in the comparison are:

  • •

    FedAvgMcMahan et al. [2017]: FedAvg is the most classic algorithm in federated learning. In fact, we can set λ𝜆\lambda to 0, transforming FedFDP into the FedAvg algorithm.

  • •

    SCAFFLODKarimireddy et al. [2020]: SCAFFOLD uses control variates (variance reduction) to correct for the ’client-drift’ in its local updates. It requires significantly fewer communication rounds and is not affected by data heterogeneity or client sampling.

  • •

    FedProxLi et al. [2020a]: FedProx introduces a proximal term to the objective function to address the issues of systems heterogeneity and statistical heterogeneity in federated learning.

  • •

    FedDynAcar et al. [2021]: FedDyn adds linear and quadratic penalty terms to the objective function to solve the problem of inconsistency between the minima of the local-device level empirical loss and those of the global empirical loss.

  • •

    ALI-DPFLLing et al. [2023]: ALI-DPFL dynamically obtains the optimal number of epochs for each round of communication by minimizing the convergence upper bound, thereby addressing the imbalance between local privacy budgets and communication resources.

  • •

    q-FFLLi et al. [2020b]: q-FFL amplifies the loss values of clients, equivalent to giving larger update weights to poorly performing clients, in order to cater to the underperforming clients, uniforming model performance across multiple devices.

A.3.3 Herterogeneity and Scalability

As shown in Table 4 and 5, we conducted additional experiments on the MNIST, FashionMNIST, and CIFAR10 datasets to compare the performance of FedFDP with that of six other algorithms in terms of Heterogeneity and Scalability. The Heterogeneity experiments were mainly conducted in three heterogeneous scenarios, extending from the default D​i​r​(0.1)𝐷𝑖𝑟0.1Dir(0.1) to include D​i​r​(0.5)𝐷𝑖𝑟0.5Dir(0.5) and D​i​r​(1)𝐷𝑖𝑟1Dir(1). Scalability was expanded from the default 10 clients to include 20 and 50 clients.

Heterogeneities. Tables 4 and 5 show that when confronted with diverse data distributions exhibiting varying levels of heterogeneity, both FedFair and FedFDP outperform baseline methods in accuracy while maintaining significant fairness. With the exception of the D​i​r​(0.5)𝐷𝑖𝑟0.5Dir(0.5) scenario, where they fall slightly short of q-FFL, they respectively demonstrated fairness improvements of 17.0% and 50% for FedFair and 30.3% and 18.9% for FedFDP compared to the best baselines in D​i​r​(0.1)𝐷𝑖𝑟0.1Dir(0.1) and D​i​r​(1.0)𝐷𝑖𝑟1.0Dir(1.0).

Scalability. Table 4 demonstrates that, with accuracy mostly superior to baselines, FedFair exhibited fairness improvements of 9.5%, 15.4%, and 0.01% across three client counts. Table 5 indicates that as the number of clients increases, FedFDP outperformed the best baselines by 0.36%, 0.18%, and 0.59% in accuracy, except in the 50 clients scenario, where it demonstrated fairness improvements of 27.8% and 24.1%.
